title: Exclusive: Woman of Steel winner Courtney Hill could quit rugby league
text:
Woman of Steel winner Courtney Hill admits she is tempted to return to professional cricket after hinting the amateur nature of women’s rugby league was becoming unsustainable as a career choice.

The Leeds Rhinos half-back was presented with the Woman of Steel award - sponsored by the Telegraph - on Sunday despite only taking up the sport full-time two seasons ago. It caps a fairy tale rise for the Australian, who swapped a professional cricket career with Brisbane Heat in the Big Bash League after moving to the UK to be with her partner, England cricketer Lauren Winfield.

The 32-year-old scored a try and two goals to help the Rhinos to their second successive Challenge Cup final victory over Castleford in July and the two sides will meet again in the Grand Final at St Helens' Totally Wicked Stadium on Friday.

But merely an hour after receiving the highest honour in women’s rugby league at Salford’s Lowry Theatre, Queensland-born Hill, who also works as a cricket coach in England, cast doubt on her rugby league future due to the toll the sport has taken on her.

“Sometimes on Monday mornings, I wake up and I feel hit by a bus, but I do feel like I’m just learning to understand the game,” said Hill. “But I think the hardest thing is women’s sport and where it’s at, particularly in rugby league.
description: Woman of Steel winner Courtney Hill admits she is tempted to return to professional cricket after hinting the amateur nature of women’s rugby league was becoming unsustainable as a career choice.
